body.p:
Louisville Kentucky.
September 1864
To His Excellency
Thos. E. Bramlette.
Gov. of Ky.
Sir.

I would respectfully submit that on the day of September I was fined before the City Court Sixty -- dollars The charge was keeping a tippling House -- I was detained at home on the day of trial -- not knowing the case would come on that day. The Docket of the Court having been continued for three or four days consecutively -- I am a poor man and unable to pay the fine. It is too late to take advantage and ask for new trial which if done I could easily prove I was not guilty as charged -- the indictment was procured by Mary Barr who bore Extreme malice towards me: Had she come before the court in my presence to prove the charges I could easily have shown she was of such bad character as not to be Entitled to credit. Since the finding of the Court she has been arraigned on a charge of stealing
I hope Your Excellency will remit the fine. I have never been guilty as charged but on the contrary. I have always tried to obey the laws
We citizens of Louisville respectfully petition your Excellency to remit the fine in the above case, Mr Pruit being a poor and deserving man

W. Lenning
J. D. Hodgkin
George C. Kofmeier
C. A. Sleade
George Bender
Joseph Raibb
Andrew Martin
E. Metcalf
H. Fossin
Joseph Kampf
Henry Block
A. Lauber
A. Kohlhepp
B Stoll
K. Metten
D. Esselmann

The above who have signed the foregoing petition, are immediate neighbors to Mr Prewett who keeps a small grocery, Mrs Barr the person refered to in the petition lives in his neighborhood, and keeps a brothel. Judgment was rendered against him by default for Sixty dollars, The statute authorises a fine of $20 -- for selling one drink -- and $60 -- for selling two or more drinks. I suppose in this case, the payment of $20 -- by Mr Prewet, would not hurt him,

Louisville City Ct
vs
Wm Prewitt
$60.
remit $40 -- of the fine
4th Oct/64
Tipling
